article.title: XML Configuration
article.para: Configuration for an HA-JDBC managed database cluster is contained in an XML file.

section.title: Locating the configuration file
section.para: The algorithm used to locate the configuration file resource at runtime is as follows:

listitem.para: Determine the potentially parameterized resource name from one of the following sources:
A config property passed to DriverManager.getConnection(String, Properties), or the config property of the DataSource, ConnectionPoolDataSource, or XADataSource.
The ha-jdbc.cluster-id.configuration system property.
Use default value: ha-jdbc.cluster-id.xml
Format the parameterized resource name using the identifier of the cluster.
Convert the formatted resource name to a URL. If the resource is not a URL, search for the resource in the classpath using the following class loaders:
Thread context class loader
Class loader of the current class
System class loader

section.title: Configuration file format
section.para: The root element of the configuration file has the following definition:

section.title: distributable
section.para: Indicates that database clusters defined in this file will be accessed by multiple JVMs. HA-JDBC leverages JGroups to handle communication between database clusters across servers.
section.programlisting: <!ELEMENT distributable EMPTY> <!ATTLIST distributable stack CDATA "udp-sync.xml" timeout CDATA "1000" >

listitem.para: Defines one of the following:
Name of a system resource containing the JGroups XML configuration.
URL of the JGroups XML configuration file.
Path of the JGroups XML configuration on the local file system.
Legacy protocol stack property string
See the JGroups wiki for assistance with customizing the protocol stack.
Indicates the number of milliseconds allowed for JGroups operations.

section.title: sync
section.para: Defines a strategy for synchronizing a database prior to activation. If the strategy contains JavaBean properties, you can override their default values.
section.programlisting: <!ELEMENT sync (property*)> <!ATTLIST sync id ID #REQUIRED class CDATA #REQUIRED >

listitem.para: Uniquely identifies this synchronization strategy. Used when invoking activation management operations.
Class name of a SynchronizationStrategy. A list of available synchronization stategies is described in the Synchronization section.

section.title: cluster
section.para: Defines the members and behavior of the database cluster.
section.programlisting: <!ELEMENT cluster (database+)> <!ATTLIST cluster balancer (simple|random|round-robin|load) #REQUIRED default-sync IDREF #REQUIRED dialect CDATA "standard" meta-data-cache (none|lazy|eager) #REQUIRED transaction-mode (parallel|serial) #REQUIRED auto-activate-schedule CDATA #IMPLIED failure-detect-schedule CDATA #IMPLIED min-threads CDATA "0" max-threads CDATA "100" max-idle CDATA "60" detect-identity-columns (true|false) "false" detect-sequences (true|false) "false" eval-current-date (true|false) "false" eval-current-time (true|false) "false" eval-current-timestamp (true|false) "false" eval-rand (true|false) "false" >

listitem.para: Defines the balancer implementation used to distribute read operations among the active nodes of this cluster.
Defines the unique identifier of the synchronization strategy to use by default when activating nodes of this cluster.
The value of this attribute defines either:
the class name of an implementation of the net.sf.hajdbc.Dialect interface.
a pre-defined alias as enumerated here.
HA-JDBC references the configured dialect for any vendor specific SQL.
Defines the strategy to use for caching database meta data.
Meta data is loaded when requested and not cached.
Meta data is loaded and cached as it is requested.
Meta data is loaded and cached as it is requested.
All necessary meta data is loaded and cached during HA-JDBC initialization.
All necessary meta data is loaded and cached during HA-JDBC initialization.

Indicates whether transactional writes should execute in serial or parallel. If your application uses distributed transactions coordinated via a transaction manager (typically provided by an application server) using the X/Open XA protocol then you should use serial mode. In serial mode, database writes execute in consistent order across databases in the cluster thereby avoiding deadlocks. If your application uses normal database transactions then you may use parallel mode. Parallel mode is obviously more efficient than serial mode. If you find that your application suffers unacceptably from SQLExceptions due to concurrent updates of the same data then you might want to use serial mode to improve fault tolerance.
Transactional writes are executed in parallel, for efficiency.
Transactional writes are executed in serial, for improved fault tolerance.

Defines a cron schedule for an asynchronous task that will automatically activate any database nodes that are alive, but inactive. Schedule should be defined in accordance with the documentation for Quartz CronExpression.

Defines a cron schedule for an asynchronous task that will proactively detect failed database nodes and deactivate them. Schedule should be defined in accordance with the documentation for Quartz CronExpression.
Defines the minimum size of the thread pool used for executing write operations.
Defines the maximum size of the thread pool used for executing write operations.
Defines the amount of time for which a non-core idle thread will remain in the thread pool before it is discarded.

Indicates whether or not identity columns should be detected (if the configured dialect supports them) and measures taken to ensure that they are replicated correctly. If enabled, you should also use an eager meta-data-cache since identity column detection requires several database meta-data queries.
Indicates whether or not sequence operations should be detected (if the configured dialect supports them) and measures taken to ensure that they are replicated correctly.
Indicates whether or not SQL statements containing non-deterministic CURRENT_DATE functions should be replaced with deterministic client-generated values.
Indicates whether or not SQL statements containing non-deterministic CURRENT_TIME functions should be replaced with deterministic client-generated values.
Indicates whether or not SQL statements containing non-deterministic CURRENT_TIMESTAMP functions should be replaced with deterministic client-generated values.
Indicates whether or not SQL statements containing non-deterministic RAND() functions should be replaced with deterministic client-generated values.

section.title: database
section.para: Defines the databases in this cluster that will be referenced via the java.sql.DriverManager facility.

listitem.para: Defines the JDBC url used to access this database.
Defines a property to be passed to the java.sql.Driver.connect() method.
Defines the user, if any, that HA-JDBC should use to connect to the database during synchronization and database failure detection.
Defines the password, if any, that HA-JDBC should use to connect to the database during synchronization and database failure detection.

section.programlisting: <!ATTLIST database id CDATA #REQUIRED weight CDATA "1" local (true|false) "false" >

listitem.para: Unique identifier for this database node.
Defines the relative weight of this database node. The weight is used by the balancer implementation to determine which node will service a read request.
Indicates that this database resides on the local machine.
The name of the property. The value of the property is defined in the element contents.
